abstracts.cdata!:
The Refinery Modification and Liquefied
            Petroleum Gas (LPG) Recovery and Distribution Project for
            Bangladesh rated as satisfactory by the Project Completion
            Report (PCR). However, the Operations Evaluation Department
            assessed both the project and the PCR as unsatisfactory
            because of the failure to implement two important components
            in the critical area of LPG distribution. On component had
            to be partly abandoned due to the fact that the anticipated
            feed was contingent on the completion of another project
            which did not materialize; another component could not be
            implemented due to higher than expected process quoted for
            shallow-bottomed tankers. The project was also plagued by
            the withdrawal of the top two choices for the general
            contractor and a catastrophic cyclone in the Chittagong area
            scattering material and work in progress. Institutional
            development is rated as negligible, since there was no
            progress on the LPG side, and the refinery already had a
            satisfactory institutional structure before the project. The
            prospects for sustainability of the project benefits are
            likely. The Bank's performance is rated as
            satisfactory, as it met the expectations of the Borrower
            with regard to the refinery modification and LPG components.
            The Borrower's performance is rated highly satisfactory
            for operation, and satisfactory for preparation,
            implementation, and covenant compliance. The most
            significant lesson from this project is that effective,
            results-oriented project preparation and design are keys to
            efficient implementation. Particularly for Bangladesh, there
            is a need to minimize the number of procurement packages and
            to minimize the delays resulting from the approval process
            by several layers of bureaucracy. Engagement of consultants
            to work alongside the beneficiaries' staff facilitated
            procurement. Finally, the dedication of the
            beneficiaries' staff helped in a large measure to
            implement the project.
